content: Good morning.
Anybody around? I plan to try to do the meeting here, in Zulip, as a text thing.
If you're watching and want to participate, chime in. I'll "start" the meeting at 5 or 10 after the hour.
On my way
OK, I'm settled in and have my coffee. I'm ready.

I'm editing an agenda for it here: https://bit.ly/2CPylzt

2020/07/29 Backdrop Ready-to-wear Initiative - Meeting #2
Ready-To-Wear #2 agenda - July 29th, 2020 Today’s R2W agenda: https://bit.ly/2CPylzt | “Zoom” link: YouTube Live event: N/A Goal: Make it easy for non-coders/non-designers to create attractive Backdrop sites Introductions What is your name? Where are you from? If you want, a quick non-ag...

Should we create a special topic for this meeting, something easy to mute for those not participating?

Example: R2W 7/12/2020
We can use this topic for the meeting. Then anyone not interested in our flood of messages can "MUTE" this topic, but the meeting will still be public for anyone interested.

@Luke McCormick - Have you seen the repo/issue queue that @jenlampton set up: https://github.com/backdrop-ops/demo/issues

backdrop-ops/demo
example backdrop site with content and configuration - backdrop-ops/demo
Yes, that sounds like a great approach
We can also put a lot of text directly into the Google Doc.
Let's begin. I'll put the link to this room in the regular R2W thread, and on the agenda

This link: https://bit.ly/3hNNFew

Backdrop CMS
The free and open source CMS that helps you build websites for businesses and non-profits.

Here's the GoogleDoc agenda: https://bit.ly/2CPylzt

2020/07/29 Backdrop Ready-to-wear Initiative - Meeting #2
Ready-To-Wear #2 agenda - July 29th, 2020 Today’s R2W agenda: https://bit.ly/2CPylzt | “Zoom” link: YouTube Live event: N/A Goal: Make it easy for non-coders/non-designers to create attractive Backdrop sites Introductions What is your name? Where are you from? If you want, a quick non-ag...
Actually beginning now :)
Restating the goal of the R2W Initiative: "People should be able to use backdrop without needing to know how to create or modify a theme."
I'm entering some text in the bottom of the Google Doc that I think addresses some of your questions.

I think we decided in the last ux/usability meeting that our first goal/deliverable was some sort of demo site where users can test themes, switch between them. This will help us 1) identify criteria for an "approved" theme and 2) identify issues in core that need to be addressed.

Initial discovery has uncovered at least three relevant details about the question:
1) Backdrop Themes only covers a portion of the relevant presentation issues - functionality that other systems call "themes" is covered by Layouts and Color sets
2) Content matters. We may have to include sample data, instructions and guides, and possibly other assets.
3) Backdrop already has some impressive built-in functionality that addresses this, and perhaps we should make it easier to find.

As Tim notes, we've realized that one way to demonstrate to users what they can do is by creating a demo site (which could be either permanent or generated on the fly by Tugboat) that shows off a choice of themes paired with appropriate layouts, content, and perhaps other factors.
I think that as an initiative, one of our goals should be to curate a list of core issues that we think are important to helping us achieve our goals.
One helpful decision to make, would be what kind of content we want to generate for our demo site.
I agree, a list of issues should be maintained. (Technically, I think some might not be "core" issues)
Do we want to borrow from something like the Umami theme - or start from scratch with a common use case?

I didn't see before now the relevant issue you created two weeks ago: https://github.com/backdrop-ops/demo/issues/2

META: Create sample content for new DEMO site · Issue #2 · backdrop-ops/demo
I don't know if we should have sub-issues for this or if this issue is enough. But, we need to decide on what content is necessary for a demo site. We may want to look to the Umami theme for Dr...
I'd prefer a "start from scratch" approach, though I acknowledge severe resource constraints, so I'm not at all opposed to borrowing existing content with compatible licenses, such as Umami.

We should keep in mind the lessons learned by Umami as we proceed. As they started, they realized that if their demo content was going to be part of Drupal it had to be 100% available under the Drupal open source license. Which meant, for them, creating all of the content new (recipes and images) from scratch, to be 100% certain that they had the rights to share it.
I've started a Sandbox project which could grow into a demo: https://live-backdrop-r2w.pantheonsite.io/
Well, it might help to think about what kind of content we think should be included (how deep we want to go), before deciding on the specific content.
The 100% from scratch is certainly cleaner; however I don't think we should preclude using material with compatible licenses, if they can be identified
For sure

What do we need to include in this site:

  • Blog post or "news" articles
• Simple views (??)
I think it's easier if there are multiple options. I think it's quicker and more effective to create several quick options than to try to find one that covers everything.
I'm a little concerned about the amount of work getting a single model set up, let alone thinking about multiple modules, right off the bat.
Demo content seems like it would be very useful, but I don't want to scope-creep R2W by including more than the minimum in MVP.
Sure, but how do we showcase themes without content?
I don't think multiple examples are needed for MVP. I specifically include them in backlog to give us freedom to go with a simple subset to get things launched.
Sure
I already have content :) https://live-backdrop-r2w.pantheonsite.io/a-cleanish-theme/cleanish-theme-sample
Drop's home page
The bar is set ;)
I'd like to move (before we run out of time) to something I think can fast-track us:
Do we have three (or more) completed Backdrop themes that are both polished enough and sufficiently different from each other to launch with?
I'd like to collect nominees.
Are you saying that if we apply a theme to that page and it looks good, then it qualifies?
Sort of, it depends on what we mean by qualfies.
That's the entire point I'm making, we need to decide what "qualifies."
"Looks good" is the first filter, but they should also look noticeably different
I'm finding this conversation difficult to have via text.
"Looks good" on what.
We only have 5 more minutes, we'll have a video chat next week and build on these issues then. This has felt very productive to me.
ok

StPaulTim said:

"Looks good" on what.

The selected sample content and layouts.
Would that be an appropriate issue for the queue? "Candidate themes" ?

• Candidate themes
  • Candidate content
  • Candidate layouts
  • Candidate color sets
  • Candidate test suites
  • Candidate modules
    ...
One issue for all, one issue for each, somewhere in between?

@Luke McCormick - I don't know if it's helpful. But, I'm creating a POSSIBLE list of element, which I think an "approved" theme might address (make them look good). The idea is that if we apply an approved theme to a site with these elements/content types and it looks good, then it has met the minimum requirements.

But, if we apply a theme to a site like this one of the elements (example: contact page) does not look good, then it's not finished.
My list is at bottom of agenda. Anyone can add to it or edit it.
Looks great!

Ok, let's call that the meeting. (My dayjob needs my time now)

(But further comments here are totally welcome)

For convenience, I'm copying Tim's suggestions for content items here:

What do we need to include in a demo site:

We need to create a minimal version of a site that we can use to “test” whether or not a theme is meeting the criteria for an “approved” theme. I’m suggesting that we start by creating abstract “tests” or ideas of what should look good on a demo site using an approved theme.

This is a list of basic pages/elements/types of content that we might expect a new theme to address. We can thin it out later.

Simple blog posts or news articles
Node page
Teaser
Contact form/page
Slideshow (???)
(Should this be a requirement, I’m not sure)
An “about” page which is basically static text
Logo and slogan
Menu
Is a single level menu sufficient or should we include a support for drop down menus as basic requirement.
Thanks @Luke McCormick

I think if you're going to include content and there's more than a few posts, there should be some fairly obvious/easy way to remove them, if someone decides they want to move forward with what they have.
That way, people aren't frustrated with having to get rid of a bunch of content they don't want one-at-a-time.

@oadaeh (Jason Flatt) - I understand your point. Keep in mind that there are two different ideas floating around. One would be to include sample content in core (like umami) and the other would be to simply create a demo site with sample content that a user can use to test themes.

We're focused on the latter right now. Just creating a place where we can test themes and possibly showcase them.

We're thinking of creating a template site that newcomes could spin up on Tugboat (which is temporary), like our current demo site, but with actual content and the ability to add themes.
Part of the immediate goal is to determine what criteria would be necessary to evaluate whether or not a theme is "ready to wear."
@StPaulTim you did mention it, and I feel like adding that much content for someone to remove might be excessive, so I was simply replying to your suggestion.
@oadaeh (Jason Flatt) - Understood. Thanks.

If anyone wants to contribute to this discussion, we do have this issue queue set up:
https://github.com/backdrop-ops/demo/issues

backdrop-ops/demo
example backdrop site with content and configuration - backdrop-ops/demo
Damn it, I failed at my timezone conversion and missed this. I'm catching up on the backlog of messages here...

This could be one outcome from this initiative: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/3240 (Needs more input)

[DX] Add Styleguide module in core. · Issue #3240 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
I have brought up this idea in other issues in the past (like #1106 and #3186)... As a themer, I would like to make sure that all possible elements have been properly styled in my theme. We are doi...
